docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Successfully integrated analytics tracking throughout the application with focus on authentication flows and user interactions.

docs.title: Analytics Events Added:
docs.text:
Page View Tracking: 

useEffect(() => {
    analytics.pageView({
        path: '/login',
        title: 'Login - LocalBridge',
    });
}, []);

Login Attempt Tracking: 

analytics.track({
    category: 'Authentication',
    action: 'Login Attempt',
    label: 'Email',
});

Successful Login: 

analytics.login(data.user.id, 'email');
analytics.formSubmit('Login Form', true);

Failed Login: 

analytics.formSubmit('Login Form', false, error.response?.data?.error);
analytics.track({
    category: 'Authentication',
    action: 'Login Failed',
    label: 'Email',
    metadata: { error: error.response?.data?.error },
});

Button Interactions: 

// Forgot Password
analytics.buttonClick('Forgot Password', 'Login Page');

// SSO Buttons
analytics.buttonClick(`SSO ${provider}`, 'Login Page');
analytics.track({
    category: 'Authentication',
    action: 'SSO Attempt',
    label: provider,
});

Error Tracking: 

analytics.error(error as Error, {
    context: 'SSO Provider Check',
    provider,
});

docs.title: Login Flow:
docs.text:
1. Page Load → pageView event
  2. User enters credentials → No tracking (privacy)
  3. Submit button clicked → Login Attempt event
  4. API call → Success or failure
  5. Success:
  6. login(userId, 'email') event
  7. formSubmit('Login Form', true) event
  8. setUser({...}) sets user properties
  9. Navigate to /chat
  10. Failure:
  11. formSubmit('Login Form', false, error) event
  12. Login Failed event with error metadata
  13. Show error toast

docs.title: SSO Flow:
docs.text:
1. SSO button clicked → buttonClick event
  2. SSO Attempt → track event
  3. Provider check → Success or error
  4. Success: Redirect to provider
  5. Error:
  6. error event with context
  7. Show error toast

docs.title: Logout Flow:
docs.text:
1. Logout triggered → logout(userId) event
  2. Clear local storage → Remove token
  3. Clear state → Remove user data
  4. Show toast → Confirmation message

docs.title: What We Track:
docs.text: ✅ Page views and navigation ✅ Button clicks and interactions ✅ Form submission success/failure ✅ Error messages (sanitized) ✅ User ID and role (for authenticated users) ✅ Performance metrics

docs.title: What We DON'T Track:
docs.text: ❌ Password values ❌ Email addresses in events (only in user properties) ❌ Personal data in event metadata ❌ Sensitive error details in production

docs.text: Implemented comprehensive analytics tracking, error monitoring, and loading state improvements to enhance observability and user experience.

docs.title: 1. Analytics Service ✅
docs.text: File: src/lib/analytics.ts

docs.title: Core Functionality:
docs.text:
• Centralized event tracking system
  • Support for multiple analytics providers
  • Development mode logging
  • Session tracking
  • Performance monitoring

docs.title: Key Methods:
docs.text:
Page Tracking: 

analytics.pageView({ path: '/chat', title: 'Chat Interface' });

Event Tracking: 

analytics.track({
    category: 'Feature',
    action: 'Used',
    label: 'Code Generation',
    value: 1500, // duration in ms
    metadata: { model: 'llama3.1' }
});

User Authentication: 

analytics.login(userId, 'google');
analytics.logout(userId);

Prototype Generation: 

analytics.prototypeGenerated({
    model: 'llama3.1:latest',
    promptLength: 150,
    durationMs: 15000,
    success: true
});

Error Tracking: 

analytics.error(error, {
    context: 'generation',
    correlationId: 'abc123'
});

Feature Usage: 

analytics.featureUsed('GitHub Sync', { repo: 'myrepo' });

Button Clicks: 

analytics.buttonClick('Generate Prototype', 'Project Detail Page');

Form Submissions: 

analytics.formSubmit('Login Form', true);

Performance Metrics: 

analytics.performance('API Response Time', 250, {
    endpoint: '/api/generate'
});

docs.text:

// Automatically sends to window.gtag if available

Custom Endpoint:

docs.title: 2. Enhanced Error Boundary ✅
docs.text: File: src/components/ErrorBoundary.tsx

docs.title: New Features:
docs.text:
Unique Error IDs: - Every error gets a unique tracking ID - Format: error_1704418800000_abc123xyz - Displayed to users for support tickets

Analytics Integration: - Automatic error tracking in analytics - Includes component stack and context - Tracks recovery attempts

Multiple Recovery Options: 1. Try Again - Resets error boundary state 2. Reload Page - Full page refresh 3. Go Home - Navigate to homepage

Error Reporting: - Custom endpoint support via VITE_ERROR_REPORTING_ENDPOINT - Sentry integration ready - Includes full error context: - Error message and stack - Component stack - URL and user agent - App version - Timestamp

User-Friendly Display: - Error ID prominently shown - Support email link - Clear recovery instructions - Development mode: Full error details - Production mode: User-friendly message

Custom Error Handler: 

<ErrorBoundary onError={(error, errorInfo) => {
    // Custom handling
    console.log('Custom error handler', error);
}}>
    <App />
</ErrorBoundary>

    }, [location]);

    return <Routes>...</Routes>;
}

docs.title: Use Loading Skeletons:
docs.text:
import { SkeletonProjectCard } from '@/components/loading/SkeletonPresets';

function ProjectsList() {
    const { data, isLoading } = useQuery('projects', fetchProjects);

    if (isLoading) {
        return (
            <div className="grid grid-cols-3 gap-6">
                {Array.from({ length: 6 }).map((_, i) => (
                    <SkeletonProjectCard key={i} />
                ))}
            </div>
        );
    }

    return <div>{/* Actual content */}</div>;
}

docs.title: Google Analytics 4 & Sentry Setup Guide
docs.text: Complete guide for setting up analytics and error tracking

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Google account
  • Admin access to LocalBridge
  • Google Analytics property (or ability to create one)

docs.title: Step 1: Create Google Analytics 4 Property
docs.text:
1. Go to Google Analytics
  2. Visit: https://analytics.google.com

  3. Sign in with your Google account

  4. Create Property

  5. Click Admin (bottom left)
  6. Click Create Property
  7. Enter property details:
    • Property name: LocalBridge
    • Reporting time zone: Your timezone
    • Currency: Your currency

  8. Click Next

  9. Business Information

  10. Industry category: Technology
  11. Business size: Select appropriate size

  12. Click Next

  13. Business Objectives

  14. Select: Examine user behavior

  15. Click Create

  16. Accept Terms

  17. Review and accept terms of service
  18. Click I Accept

docs.title: Step 2: Set Up Data Stream
docs.text:
1. Choose Platform

  2. Select Web

  3. Configure Stream

  4. Website URL: https://your-domain.com
  5. Stream name: LocalBridge Web

  6. Click Create stream

  7. Get Measurement ID

  8. Copy the Measurement ID (format: G-XXXXXXXXXX)
  9. Keep this page open for later

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Enhanced Measurement
docs.text:
1. In Data Stream Settings
  2. Click Enhanced measurement

  3. Enable these options:

    • ✅ Page views
    • ✅ Scrolls
    • ✅ Outbound clicks
    • ✅ Site search
    • ✅ Form interactions
    • ✅ File downloads

  4. Save Settings

  5. Click Save

docs.title: Step 3: Configure Frontend
docs.text:
1. Update main.tsx
// src/main.tsx
import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';
import * as Sentry from '@sentry/react';
import App from './App';
import './index.css';

// Initialize Sentry
if (import.meta.env.PROD && import.meta.env.VITE_SENTRY_DSN) {
  Sentry.init({
    dsn: import.meta.env.VITE_SENTRY_DSN,
    integrations: [
      new Sentry.BrowserTracing({
        // Set tracePropagationTargets to control distributed tracing
        tracePropagationTargets: [
          'localhost',
          /^https:\/\/yourserver\.io\/api/,
        ],
      }),
      new Sentry.Replay({
        maskAllText: true,
        blockAllMedia: true,
      }),
    ],

    // Performance Monitoring
    tracesSampleRate: 1.0, // Capture 100% of transactions

    // Session Replay
    replaysSessionSampleRate: 0.1, // 10% of sessions
    replaysOnErrorSampleRate: 1.0, // 100% of sessions with errors

    // Environment
    environment: import.meta.env.MODE,

    // Release tracking
    release: import.meta.env.VITE_APP_VERSION || '1.0.0',

    // Before send hook (filter sensitive data)
    beforeSend(event, hint) {
      // Don't send events in development
      if (import.meta.env.DEV) {
        return null;
      }

      // Filter sensitive data
      if (event.request) {
        delete event.request.cookies;
        delete event.request.headers;
      }

      return event;
    },
  });
}

ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')!).render(
  <React.StrictMode>
    <App />
  </React.StrictMode>
);

docs.title: Step 4: Configure Backend
docs.text:
1. Update server/index.ts
// server/index.ts
import express from 'express';
import * as Sentry from '@sentry/node';
import { ProfilingIntegration } from '@sentry/profiling-node';

const app = express();

// Initialize Sentry (before any other middleware)
if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' && process.env.SENTRY_DSN) {
  Sentry.init({
    dsn: process.env.SENTRY_DSN,
    integrations: [
      new Sentry.Integrations.Http({ tracing: true }),
      new Sentry.Integrations.Express({ app }),
      new ProfilingIntegration(),
    ],
    tracesSampleRate: 1.0,
    profilesSampleRate: 1.0,
    environment: process.env.NODE_ENV,
  });

  // RequestHandler creates a separate execution context
  app.use(Sentry.Handlers.requestHandler());

  // TracingHandler creates a trace for every incoming request
  app.use(Sentry.Handlers.tracingHandler());
}

// ... your routes ...

// Error handler (must be before any other error middleware)
if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'production' && process.env.SENTRY_DSN) {
  app.use(Sentry.Handlers.errorHandler());
}

// ... rest of your app ...

docs.title: Enterprise Code Review & Enhancement Report
docs.text: Date: 2026-01-04 System: LocalBridge - AI Prototyping Tool Review Type: Comprehensive Enterprise Standards Audit

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
Overall system quality: GOOD with areas for improvement. The codebase demonstrates solid architecture but requires enhancements for enterprise production deployment.

Priority Levels: - 🔴 CRITICAL: Must fix before production - 🟡 HIGH: Should fix soon - 🟢 MEDIUM: Recommended improvements - 🔵 LOW: Nice to have

docs.title: 1.1 GitHub Token Storage (CRITICAL)
docs.text:
Location: server/db/schema.ts - projects table Issue: GitHub tokens stored in plaintext in database 

githubToken: text('github_token'),  // ❌ PLAINTEXT!
Impact: Token compromise = full repo access Fix Required: 
// Use encryption at rest
import { encrypt, decrypt } from '../lib/crypto.js';

// Before storing
const encryptedToken = await encrypt(githubToken);
await db.insert(projects).values({ githubToken: encryptedToken });

// When retrieving
const decryptedToken = await decrypt(project.githubToken);

docs.title: 1.2 Model Input Validation (CRITICAL)
docs.text:
Location: server/routes/generate.ts:15 Issue: Model parameter accepts any string 

model: z.string().default('llama3.1:latest'),  // ❌ No whitelist!
Impact: Potential command injection or resource exhaustion Fix Required: 
model: z.enum([
    'llama3.1:latest',
    'codellama:latest',
    'qwen2.5-coder:latest',
    'deepseek-coder:latest'
]).default('llama3.1:latest'),

docs.title: 1.3 Rate Limiting Missing (CRITICAL)
docs.text:
Location: All API routes Issue: No rate limiting on expensive operations (AI generation, GitHub sync) Impact: DoS attacks, resource exhaustion Fix Required: 

import rateLimit from 'express-rate-limit';

const generateLimiter = rateLimit({
    windowMs: 15 * 60 * 1000, // 15 minutes
    max: 10, // 10 requests per window
    message: 'Too many generation requests, please try again later'
});

router.post('/prototype', generateLimiter, async (req, res) => {
    // ...
});

docs.title: 1.4 Input Sanitization
docs.text:
Location: server/routes/generate.ts:34-46 Issue: User prompt directly interpolated into system prompt 

const systemPrompt = `...User Request: ${prompt}...`;  // ❌ No sanitization
Impact: Prompt injection attacks Fix: 
import { sanitizeInput } from '../lib/sanitizer.js';
const sanitizedPrompt = sanitizeInput(prompt, { maxLength: 2000 });

docs.title: 1.5 Error Information Leakage
docs.text:
Location: Multiple routes Issue: Detailed error messages exposed to client 

res.status(500).json({ error: 'Failed...', details: error.message });  // ❌
Fix: 
// Log detailed error server-side
logger.error('Generation failed:', error);
// Return generic message to client
res.status(500).json({ error: 'An error occurred. Please try again.' });

docs.title: 2.1 Missing Database Indexes
docs.text:
Location: server/db/schema.ts Issue: Missing composite indexes for common queries Fix Required: 

// Add to prototypes table
export const prototypes = pgTable('prototypes', {
    // ... existing fields
}, (table) => ({
    // ... existing indexes
    projectUserIdx: index('prototype_project_user_idx').on(table.projectId, table.userId),
    createdAtIdx: index('prototype_created_at_idx').on(table.createdAt),
}));

docs.title: 2.2 N+1 Query Problem
docs.text:
Location: server/routes/projects.ts:28-52 Issue: Loading prototypes separately for each project Fix: 

// Use Drizzle's with clause for eager loading
const result = await db.query.projects.findMany({
    where: conditions.length > 0 ? and(...conditions) : undefined,
    with: {
        prototypes: {
            limit: 10,  // Limit to prevent huge payloads
            orderBy: desc(prototypes.createdAt)
        }
    }
});

docs.title: 2.3 No Caching Strategy
docs.text:
Issue: Repeated queries for same data Fix: 

import Redis from 'ioredis';
const redis = new Redis(process.env.REDIS_URL);

// Cache project data
const cacheKey = `project:${id}`;
const cached = await redis.get(cacheKey);
if (cached) return JSON.parse(cached);

const project = await db.query.projects.findFirst({...});
await redis.setex(cacheKey, 300, JSON.stringify(project)); // 5 min TTL

docs.title: 2.4 Large Code Generation Timeout
docs.text:
Location: server/routes/generate.ts Issue: No timeout for AI generation Fix: 

const GENERATION_TIMEOUT = 120000; // 2 minutes

const timeoutPromise = new Promise((_, reject) => 
    setTimeout(() => reject(new Error('Generation timeout')), GENERATION_TIMEOUT)
);

await Promise.race([
    streamChat(systemPrompt, model, callback),
    timeoutPromise
]);

docs.title: 3.1 No Transaction Handling
docs.text:
Location: server/routes/generate.ts:77-105 Issue: Prototype and version created separately (not atomic) Fix: 

await db.transaction(async (tx) => {
    const [newPrototype] = await tx.insert(prototypes).values({...}).returning();

    await tx.insert(prototypeVersions).values({
        prototypeId: newPrototype.id,
        // ...
    });
});

docs.title: 3.2 GitHub Sync Failure Handling
docs.text:
Location: server/routes/projects.ts:164-273 Issue: Partial failures leave inconsistent state Fix: 

// Add retry logic
import { retry } from '../lib/retry.js';

const syncResult = await retry(async () => {
    // GitHub operations
}, { maxAttempts: 3, backoff: 'exponential' });

docs.title: 3.3 Missing Health Checks
docs.text:
Issue: No monitoring of dependencies (DB, Ollama) Fix: 

router.get('/health', async (req, res) => {
    const checks = {
        database: await checkDatabase(),
        ollama: await checkOllama(),
        redis: await checkRedis()
    };

    const healthy = Object.values(checks).every(c => c.healthy);
    res.status(healthy ? 200 : 503).json(checks);
});

docs.title: 3.4 No Graceful Shutdown
docs.text:
Location: server/index.ts Fix: 

process.on('SIGTERM', async () => {
    console.log('SIGTERM received, shutting down gracefully...');
    server.close(() => {
        db.end();
        redis.quit();
        process.exit(0);
    });
});

docs.title: 4.1 Inconsistent Error Handling
docs.text:
Issue: Mix of try-catch patterns Fix: Implement centralized error handler 

// middleware/errorHandler.ts
export const errorHandler = (err, req, res, next) => {
    logger.error(err);

    if (err instanceof ValidationError) {
        return res.status(400).json({ error: err.message });
    }

    res.status(500).json({ error: 'Internal server error' });
};

docs.title: 4.2 Magic Numbers
docs.text:
Location: Throughout codebase 

.substring(0, 200)  // ❌ What is 200?
Fix: 
const MAX_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH = 200;
.substring(0, MAX_DESCRIPTION_LENGTH)

docs.title: 4.3 Logging Inconsistency
docs.text:
Issue: Mix of console.log and console.error Fix: Use structured logging 

import winston from 'winston';

const logger = winston.createLogger({
    level: process.env.LOG_LEVEL || 'info',
    format: winston.format.json(),
    transports: [
        new winston.transports.File({ filename: 'error.log', level: 'error' }),
        new winston.transports.File({ filename: 'combined.log' })
    ]
});

docs.title: 4.4 TypeScript Strictness
docs.text:
Issue: Using any types in several places 

req.user as any  // ❌
Fix: 
interface AuthenticatedRequest extends Request {
    user?: {
        id: string;
        email: string;
        role: string;
    };
}

docs.title: 5.1 Audit Logging
docs.text: Status: Partially implemented Missing: Comprehensive audit trail for all operations Add: - User authentication events - Failed access attempts - Data modifications - Export capabilities

docs.text:
Status: NOT IMPLEMENTED Required: 

# Add to package.json scripts
"backup:db": "pg_dump $DATABASE_URL > backups/db_$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S).sql"

docs.title: 5.3 Monitoring & Observability
docs.text: Status: NOT IMPLEMENTED Add: - Prometheus metrics - OpenTelemetry tracing - Performance monitoring - Error tracking (Sentry)

docs.title: 5.4 API Versioning
docs.text:
Issue: No API versioning strategy Fix: 

app.use('/api/v1/projects', projectsRouter);
app.use('/api/v1/generate', generateRouter);

docs.title: 5.5 Request Validation Middleware
docs.text:
Add: 

import { validateRequest } from '../middleware/validation.js';

router.post('/prototype', 
    validateRequest(generatePrototypeSchema),
    async (req, res) => {
        // Schema already validated
    }

docs.title: 5.6 CORS Configuration

Location: server/index.ts Issue: May be too permissive Review: 

app.use(cors({
    origin: process.env.ALLOWED_ORIGINS?.split(',') || 'http://localhost:8080',
    credentials: true,
    maxAge: 86400
}));

Status: MISSING Required:

        const response = await request(app)

docs.title: ✅ Phase 2 Verification & Testing Guide
docs.text: The "One Project = One Prototype" architecture is now fully implemented! This guide will help you verify the new iterative workflow.

docs.title: 1. Create a New Project
docs.text:
1. Go to the dashboard.
  2. Click "New Project".
  3. Give it a name (e.g., "Verification Demo") and create it.
  4. Expected: You land on the Project Detail page. The left panel shows "Prompt Templates" and "Generate Prototype". The right panel shows "No Prototype Yet".

docs.title: 2. Generate Initial Prototype
docs.text:
1. In the "Description" box, enter a simple prompt:

    "A login card with email, password, and a gradient background."

  2. Click "Generate Code".
  3. Expected:
  4. Loading state appears.
  5. Code streams into the preview area.
  6. Once complete, the left panel switches to "Conversation History".
  7. Your prompt appears in the history as "You".
  8. The AI response "Generated prototype..." appears in the history is "AI Assistant".
  9. The right panel shows the live preview of the login card.

docs.title: 3. Iterative Enhancement
docs.text:
1. In the left panel, below the history, you should see the "Enhance Prototype" card.
  2. Enter an enhancement prompt:

    "Add a 'Forgot Password' link and make the button blue."

  3. Click "Enhance Prototype".
  4. Expected:
  5. "Enhancing..." loading state on the button.
  6. A toast notification appears upon success.
  7. The preview updates automatically to show the new blue button and link.
  8. The "Conversation History" updates with your new prompt and the AI's confirmation ("Enhanced to version 2").
  9. The version badge near the top updates to v2.

docs.title: 4. Test Version Switching
docs.text:
1. Hover over the v1 badge in the Conversation History (on the first "Generated prototype" message).
  2. Click on the badge/message.
  3. Expected:
  4. A toast appears: "Viewing Version 1".
  5. The preview reverts to the initial generated code (e.g., without the blue button).
  6. The code editor (if opened) shows the older code.
  7. Click on the v2 badge (latest).
  8. Expected:
  9. Preview updates to the latest version (with blue button).
  10. "Viewing Version 2" toast (or simply resets if it's the current version).

docs.title: 5. Page Reload Persistence
docs.text:
1. Refresh the page.
  2. Expected:
  3. The latest version (v2) is loaded automatically.
  4. The entire Conversation History is preserved and displayed.
  5. You can continue enhancing immediately.

docs.title: 🔍 Troubleshooting
docs.text: Issue Check History empty after reload Database migration might not have applied. Run npm run db:push again. "Enhance" fails Check terminal logs for API errors. Ensure Ollama is running (ollama serve). Preview looks broken The LLM might have generated invalid React code. Try a simpler prompt or retry enhancement.

docs.text:
Now that the core iterative loop is working, future improvements (Phase 3) could include: - Version Switching: Clicking a message in history to revert the preview to that version. - Diff View: Visually comparing code changes between versions. - Branching: Creating alternative directions for a prototype.

docs.title: 1. Model Validation (CRITICAL)
docs.text:
Before: 

model: z.string().default('llama3.1:latest')  // ❌ Any string accepted

After: 

const ALLOWED_MODELS = [
    'llama3.1:latest',
    'codellama:latest',
    'qwen2.5-coder:latest',
    'deepseek-coder:latest'
] as const;

model: z.enum(ALLOWED_MODELS).default('llama3.1:latest')  // ✅ Whitelist only

Impact: Prevents command injection and resource exhaustion attacks

docs.title: 2. Prompt Length Limit (CRITICAL)
docs.text:
Before: 

prompt: z.string().min(10)  // ❌ No max length

After: 

prompt: z.string().min(10).max(5000)  // ✅ Limited to 5000 chars

Impact: Prevents DoS attacks via extremely long prompts

docs.title: 3. Atomic Transactions (CRITICAL)
docs.text:
Before: 

// Separate operations - can fail partially
const prototype = await db.insert(prototypes).values({...});
await db.insert(prototypeVersions).values({...});  // ❌ Can fail leaving orphan

After: 

// Atomic transaction - all or nothing
const result = await db.transaction(async (tx) => {
    const prototype = await tx.insert(prototypes).values({...});
    await tx.insert(prototypeVersions).values({...});
    return { prototype, versionNumber };
});  // ✅ Atomic operation

Impact: Prevents data inconsistency

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The Defense Air-Gapped Operations module provides enterprise-grade security tools for classified environments, SCIF facilities, and air-gapped networks. This system ensures complete network isolation while providing essential security operations including:

  • AES-256 Encryption for files and text
  • Audit Logging for all security events
  • Session Management with recording and playback
  • Network Isolation Verification
  • Secure File Transfer with integrity checking
  • Terminal Operations for system diagnostics

[!IMPORTANT] This module is designed for classified operations. All actions are logged and monitored for security compliance.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Access to Enterprise Solutions Hub
  • Appropriate clearance level
  • Understanding of air-gapped security protocols

docs.title: Accessing the Module
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Enterprise Solutions from the main menu
  2. Click on the Defense tab (marked with red "Classified" badge)
  3. Review the security notice and proceed

docs.title: Step-by-Step Activation
docs.text:
1. Locate the Air-Gap Protocol Card
  2. Find the card labeled "Air-Gap Protocol" on the Defense page

  3. Current status will show "OPEN configuration" when inactive

  4. Click Activate Protocol

  5. Press the red "Activate Protocol" button

  6. System will immediately enter isolated mode

  7. Verify Activation

  8. Status changes to "ISOLATED from public networks"
  9. AIR-GAPPED badge appears in the header

  10. Security dashboard becomes accessible

  11. Automatic Session Start

  12. A new security session is automatically created
  13. All actions will be logged to this session

[!WARNING] Once activated, the system will attempt to block all external network connections. Ensure all necessary files are available locally before activation.

docs.title: Deactivation
docs.text: To deactivate air-gap mode: 1. Click the "Deactivate Protocol" button 2. Current session will be automatically ended 3. System returns to OPEN configuration

docs.title: Security Dashboard
docs.text: The Security Dashboard provides real-time monitoring of your air-gapped environment.

docs.title: Status Overview
docs.text:
• Security State: OPEN, ISOLATED, or LOCKED
  • Clearance Level: Current user clearance (UNCLASSIFIED → TOP_SECRET)
  • Network Status: ISOLATED or CONNECTED
  • Integrity Score: System integrity percentage (target: 100%)

docs.title: System Metrics
docs.text:
• Uptime: Time since air-gap activation
  • Total Sessions: Number of security sessions created
  • Active Sessions: Currently running sessions
  • Audit Events: Total security events logged

docs.title: Current Session
docs.text:
• Session ID: Unique identifier for tracking
  • Started: Session start time
  • Events: Number of events in current session
  • Status: Active or Inactive

docs.title: Recent Audit Events
docs.text: View the last 5 security events with: - Event description - Event type (MODE_CHANGE, FILE_TRANSFER, ENCRYPTION, etc.) - Timestamp - Severity level (low, medium, high, critical)

docs.title: Emergency Actions
docs.text:
• Emergency Lockdown: Immediately locks the system and terminates all sessions
  • Use only in case of security breach

docs.title: Exporting Audit Logs
docs.text:
1. Click "Export Logs" button on the dashboard
  2. Logs are downloaded as JSON file
  3. File includes all events with timestamps and metadata

docs.title: Secure File Transfer
docs.text: Transfer files securely with optional encryption and integrity verification.

docs.title: Uploading Files
docs.text:
1. Navigate to File Transfer Tab

  2. Click "File Transfer" in the sub-navigation

  3. Configure Encryption (Optional)

  4. Check "Enable AES-256 Encryption"
  5. Enter a strong password

  6. Toggle "Show password" if needed

  7. Select Files

  8. Click the upload area or drag and drop files
  9. Multiple files can be selected

  10. Each file is processed individually

  11. Monitor Progress

  12. Files appear in the transfer queue
  13. Progress bar shows encryption/transfer status

  14. SHA-256 hash is calculated for integrity

  15. Transfer Complete

  16. Green checkmark indicates success
  17. Download button becomes available

docs.title: Downloading Files
docs.text:
1. Locate File in Queue

  2. Find the completed transfer

  3. Click Download Button

  4. If encrypted, file is automatically decrypted using the password

  5. If not encrypted, original file is downloaded

  6. Verify Integrity

  7. Compare SHA-256 hash if needed
  8. Hash is displayed under each file

docs.title: Transfer Queue Management
docs.text:
• Remove Transfer: Click trash icon to remove from queue
  • Clear Completed: Remove all completed transfers at once

[!TIP] Always verify file integrity using the SHA-256 hash, especially for critical files.

docs.title: Encryption & Decryption
docs.text: Encrypt and decrypt text or files using AES-256-GCM encryption.

docs.title: Encrypting Text
docs.text:
1. Navigate to Encryption Tab

  2. Click "Encryption" in the sub-navigation

  3. Set Password

  4. Enter a strong encryption password

  5. Or click the key icon to generate a random key

  6. Enter Plaintext

  7. Type or paste text to encrypt in the text area

  8. Click "Encrypt Text"

  9. System generates encrypted ciphertext

  10. Salt and IV (Initialization Vector) are also generated

  11. Save Encrypted Data

  12. Copy the ciphertext, salt, and IV
  13. Or click "Export" to download as JSON file

[!IMPORTANT] Save all three values: ciphertext, salt, and IV. All are required for decryption.

docs.title: Decrypting Text
docs.text:
1. Switch to Decrypt Tab

  2. Click the "Decrypt" tab

  3. Enter Encrypted Data

  4. Paste ciphertext
  5. Paste salt

  6. Paste IV

  7. Enter Password

  8. Must be the same password used for encryption

  9. Click "Decrypt Text"

  10. Decrypted text appears below
  11. If password is incorrect, error message is shown

docs.title: Random Key Generation
docs.text:
• Click the key icon next to password field
  • System generates a cryptographically secure random key
  • Key is automatically set as the password

docs.title: Threat Intelligence
docs.text: Monitor global threat signals and security alerts in real-time.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• DEFCON Level: Current defense readiness condition
  • SIGINT Status: Signals intelligence monitoring status
  • System Uptime: Network uptime percentage
  • Active Nodes: Visual grid of monitoring nodes
  • Live Signal Feed: Real-time intercepted signals

docs.title: Signal Types
docs.text:
• Intercept (Blue): Communication intercepts
  • Threat (Red): Identified threats
  • Anomaly (Yellow): Unusual patterns

docs.title: Signal Information
docs.text:
Each signal displays: - Source (SAT-4, GND-STATION-Lagos, INTEL-BUJA, DRONE-RECON) - Geographic coordinates - Severity level - Timestamp

[!NOTE] Threat Intelligence requires active air-gap mode to function.

docs.title: Security
docs.text:
1. Always Verify Air-Gap Status
  2. Check for AIR-GAPPED badge in header

  3. Verify network status shows "ISOLATED"

  4. Use Strong Passwords

  5. Minimum 16 characters
  6. Mix of letters, numbers, and symbols

  7. Consider using generated keys

  8. Verify File Integrity

  9. Always check SHA-256 hashes

  10. Compare before and after transfer

  11. Regular Integrity Checks

  12. Run integrity command periodically
  13. Monitor audit logs for anomalies

docs.title: Operational
docs.text:
1. Session Management
  2. Start new session for each work period
  3. Export session logs before ending

  4. Review audit events regularly

  5. File Transfers

  6. Encrypt sensitive files
  7. Keep transfer queue organized

  8. Clear completed transfers

  9. Documentation

  10. Export audit logs regularly
  11. Maintain offline backups
  12. Document all security incidents

docs.title: Air-Gap Protocol Won't Activate
docs.text:
Problem: Button doesn't respond or activation fails

Solutions: 1. Refresh the page 2. Check browser console for errors 3. Verify you have appropriate clearance 4. Try logging out and back in

docs.title: File Transfer Fails
docs.text:
Problem: File upload or encryption fails

Solutions: 1. Check file size (large files may take longer) 2. Verify password is set if encryption is enabled 3. Try with a smaller file first 4. Check browser console for errors

docs.title: Decryption Fails
docs.text:
Problem: "Decryption failed" error message

Solutions: 1. Verify password is correct 2. Ensure salt and IV are correctly copied 3. Check for extra spaces in pasted values 4. Verify ciphertext is complete

docs.title: Terminal Commands Not Working
docs.text:
Problem: Commands return errors or don't execute

Solutions: 1. Type help to see available commands 2. Check command syntax 3. Ensure air-gap mode is active 4. Try clear and retry command

docs.title: Network Alerts in Air-Gap Mode
docs.text:
Problem: "Network connection detected" alerts

Solutions: 1. Disconnect physical network cable 2. Disable Wi-Fi 3. Check for VPN connections 4. Use network command to diagnose

docs.title: Q: What happens to my data when I activate air-gap mode?
docs.text: A: All data remains local. The system attempts to block external network connections and all operations are performed offline.

docs.title: Q: Can I transfer files between air-gapped systems?
docs.text: A: Yes, use the Secure File Transfer feature to encrypt files, then transfer via approved physical media (USB drives, etc.).

docs.title: Q: How long are audit logs kept?
docs.text: A: The system keeps the last 1000 audit events in memory. Export logs regularly for permanent storage.

docs.title: Q: What encryption algorithm is used?
docs.text: A: AES-256-GCM (Galois/Counter Mode) with PBKDF2 key derivation (100,000 iterations).

docs.title: Q: Can I use this on a mobile device?
docs.text: A: The interface is responsive and works on tablets. Phone screens may be too small for optimal use.

docs.title: Q: What should I do if I forget my encryption password?
docs.text: A: Encrypted data cannot be recovered without the password. Always store passwords securely.

docs.title: Q: How do I know if my system is truly air-gapped?
docs.text: A: Use the network command in the terminal to verify isolation. The dashboard also shows network status.

docs.title: Q: Can multiple users access air-gap mode simultaneously?
docs.text: A: Each user has their own session. Sessions are isolated and independently managed.

docs.title: Q: What's the difference between ISOLATED and LOCKED states?
docs.text: A: ISOLATED is normal air-gap mode. LOCKED is emergency mode that terminates all sessions and requires administrator intervention.

docs.title: Q: How do I export my session data?
docs.text: A: Use the "Export Logs" button on the dashboard or the export command in the terminal.

docs.title: Support
docs.text:
For technical support or security incidents: - Contact your system administrator - Review audit logs for detailed error information - Export logs before reporting issues

interface SecurityContextType {
    // Legacy compatibility
    isRedactedMode: boolean;
    toggleRedactedMode: () => void;
    clearanceLevel: ClearanceLevel;

    // Enhanced features
    securityState: 'OPEN' | 'ISOLATED' | 'LOCKED';
    currentSession: Session | null;
    auditLog: AuditEvent[];
    metrics: SecurityMetrics;
    isNetworkIsolated: boolean;

    // Actions
    setClearanceLevel: (level: ClearanceLevel) => void;
    logAuditEvent: (type: string, description: string, severity: string) => void;
    startSession: () => void;
    endSession: () => void;
    emergencyLockdown: () => void;
    exportAuditLog: () => string;
    clearAuditLog: () => void;
    getSessionHistory: () => Session[];
}

    timestamp: Date;
    type: string;
    description: string;
    severity: 'low' | 'medium' | 'high' | 'critical';
    userId?: string;
    metadata?: Record<string, any>;
}

interface Session {
    id: string;
    startTime: Date;
    endTime?: Date;
    clearanceLevel: ClearanceLevel;

}

interface SecurityMetrics {

    integrityScore: number;

    activeSessions: number;
    auditEventCount: number;
}

        toggleRedactedMode,
        logAuditEvent,
        currentSession
    } = useSecurity();

    const handleAction = () => {
        logAuditEvent('USER_ACTION', 'Button clicked', 'low');
        // ... perform action
    };

    return (
        <div>
            {isRedactedMode && <p>Air-gap active</p>}
            <button onClick={handleAction}>Do Something</button>
        </div>
    );
}

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
1. Password Strength: Minimum 16 characters recommended

  5. Key Derivation: 100,000 iterations provides strong protection

docs.title: useNetworkMonitor
docs.text:
function useNetworkMonitor(isAirGapMode: boolean): {

docs.title: File Transfer Flow
docs.text:
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant Component
    participant Encryption
    participant Context

    User->>Component: Select file
    Component->>Component: Add to queue
    User->>Component: Click upload
    Component->>Encryption: encryptFile(file, password)
    Encryption->>Encryption: Generate salt & IV

docs.title: Option 2: Docker with Reverse Proxy
docs.text:
1. Build the image: 

    docker build -t chat-companion:v1.0.0 .

  2. Run with Nginx reverse proxy: 

    docker run -d \
  --name chat-companion \
  --restart unless-stopped \
  -p 8080:80 \
  --env-file .env.production.local \
  chat-companion:v1.0.0

  3. Configure Nginx reverse proxy (on host): 

    server {
    listen 443 ssl http2;
    server_name your-domain.com;

    ssl_certificate /path/to/cert.pem;
    ssl_certificate_key /path/to/key.pem;

    location / {
        proxy_pass http://localhost:8080;
        proxy_http_version 1.1;
        proxy_set_header Upgrade $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header Connection 'upgrade';
        proxy_set_header Host $host;
        proxy_cache_bypass $http_upgrade;
        proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
        proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
    }
}

server {
    listen 80;
    server_name your-domain.com;
    return 301 https://$server_name$request_uri;
}

docs.title: Kubernetes Deployment
docs.text:
1. Create namespace: 

    kubectl create namespace chat-companion

  2. Create secrets: 

    kubectl create secret generic chat-companion-env \
  --from-env-file=.env.production.local \
  -n chat-companion

  3. Apply Kubernetes manifests: 

    # deployment.yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  name: chat-companion
  namespace: chat-companion
spec:
  replicas: 3
  selector:
    matchLabels:
      app: chat-companion
  template:
    metadata:
      labels:
        app: chat-companion
    spec:
      containers:
      - name: chat-companion
        image: chat-companion:v1.0.0
        ports:
        - containerPort: 80
        envFrom:
        - secretRef:
            name: chat-companion-env
        resources:
          requests:
            memory: "128Mi"
            cpu: "100m"
          limits:
            memory: "256Mi"
            cpu: "200m"
        livenessProbe:
          httpGet:
            path: /health
            port: 80
          initialDelaySeconds: 30
          periodSeconds: 10
        readinessProbe:
          httpGet:
            path: /health
            port: 80
          initialDelaySeconds: 5
          periodSeconds: 5
---
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  name: chat-companion
  namespace: chat-companion
spec:
  selector:
    app: chat-companion
  ports:
  - port: 80
    targetPort: 80
  type: LoadBalancer


kubectl apply -f deployment.yaml

RUN chmod +x /docker-entrypoint.sh

ENTRYPOINT ["/docker-entrypoint.sh"]

#!/bin/sh
set -e

# Start Ollama in background
ollama serve &

# Wait for Ollama to be ready
sleep 5

# Pull models if not exists
if ! ollama list | grep -q "llama3.1"; then
  ollama pull llama3.1:latest
fi

# Run migrations
npm run db:migrate

# Start application
exec npm start

docs.title: Step 3: Create docker-compose.yml
docs.text:
version: '3.8'

services:
  app:
    build: .
    ports:
      - "3000:3000"
      - "11434:11434"
    environment:
      - NODE_ENV=production
      - DATABASE_URL=postgresql://postgres:password@db:5432/localbridge
      - JWT_SECRET=${JWT_SECRET}
      - SESSION_SECRET=${SESSION_SECRET}
    depends_on:
      - db
    volumes:
      - ollama_data:/data
    restart: unless-stopped

  db:
    image: postgres:14-alpine
    environment:
      - POSTGRES_DB=localbridge
      - POSTGRES_USER=postgres
      - POSTGRES_PASSWORD=password
    volumes:
      - postgres_data:/var/lib/postgresql/data
    restart: unless-stopped

  nginx:
    image: nginx:alpine
    ports:
      - "80:80"
      - "443:443"
    volumes:
      - ./nginx.conf:/etc/nginx/nginx.conf:ro
      - ./ssl:/etc/nginx/ssl:ro
    depends_on:
      - app
    restart: unless-stopped

volumes:
  postgres_data:
  ollama_data:

docs.text:
# Create backup script
sudo nano /usr/local/bin/backup-localbridge.sh

#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/var/backups/localbridge"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

mkdir -p $BACKUP_DIR

# Backup database
pg_dump localbridge | gzip > $BACKUP_DIR/db_$DATE.sql.gz

# Backup application data
tar -czf $BACKUP_DIR/data_$DATE.tar.gz /opt/LocalBridge

# Keep only last 30 days
find $BACKUP_DIR -name "*.gz" -mtime +30 -delete

echo "Backup completed: $DATE"

# Make executable
sudo chmod +x /usr/local/bin/backup-localbridge.sh

# Add to crontab
sudo crontab -e
# Add: 0 2 * * * /usr/local/bin/backup-localbridge.sh

docs.title: AI Models for Prototype Generation
docs.text: This document describes the available AI models for generating prototypes in LocalBridge.

docs.title: 1. Llama 3.1 (Recommended)
docs.text:
• Model ID: llama3.1:latest
  • Best For: General-purpose code generation
  • Strengths:
  • Excellent balance of speed and quality
  • Great understanding of React/TypeScript patterns
  • Good at following instructions
  • Use When: You want reliable, high-quality code generation

docs.title: 2. Code Llama
docs.text:
• Model ID: codellama:latest
  • Best For: Specialized coding tasks
  • Strengths:
  • Optimized specifically for code
  • Strong understanding of programming concepts
  • Good at complex logic
  • Use When: You need advanced programming logic or algorithms

docs.title: 3. Qwen 2.5 Coder
docs.text:
• Model ID: qwen2.5-coder:latest
  • Best For: Advanced code generation
  • Strengths:
  • Latest generation coding model
  • Excellent code quality
  • Strong TypeScript support
  • Use When: You want cutting-edge code generation capabilities

docs.title: 4. DeepSeek Coder
docs.text:
• Model ID: deepseek-coder:latest
  • Best For: Optimized code generation
  • Strengths:
  • Fast inference
  • Clean, efficient code
  • Good at modern frameworks
  • Use When: You prioritize speed and clean code structure

docs.title: How to Use
docs.text:
1. Select Model: In the prototype generation panel, use the "AI Model" dropdown
  2. Choose Based on Need: Pick the model that best fits your use case
  3. Generate: The selected model will be used for code generation
  4. Version History: Each version tracks which model was used

docs.title: Model Requirements
docs.text:
To use these models, ensure they are pulled in your local Ollama instance:

# Pull all recommended models
ollama pull llama3.1:latest
ollama pull codellama:latest
ollama pull qwen2.5-coder:latest
ollama pull deepseek-coder:latest

docs.title: Tips for Best Results
docs.text:
• Start with Llama 3.1: It's the most reliable for general use
  • Experiment: Try different models for the same prompt to compare results
  • Version Control: Use the version history to compare outputs from different models
  • Specific Tasks: Use specialized models (Code Llama, DeepSeek) for complex logic

docs.title: Performance Considerations
docs.text:
• Model Size: Larger models produce better results but are slower
  • Hardware: Ensure your system has adequate RAM and GPU for the selected model
  • Streaming: All models support real-time streaming for immediate feedback

docs.title: Complete Flow Example
docs.text:
// 1. Login
const loginResponse = await fetch('http://localhost:3001/api/auth/login', {
  method: 'POST',
  headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
  body: JSON.stringify({
    email: 'user@example.com',
    password: 'password123'
  })
});

const { token, user } = await loginResponse.json();

// 2. Create Project
const projectResponse = await fetch('http://localhost:3001/api/projects', {
  method: 'POST',
  headers: {
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}`
  },
  body: JSON.stringify({
    name: 'My Project',
    description: 'Test project'
  })
});

const project = await projectResponse.json();

// 3. Generate Prototype
const generateResponse = await fetch('http://localhost:3001/api/generate/prototype', {
  method: 'POST',
  headers: {
    'Content-Type': 'application/json',
    'Authorization': `Bearer ${token}`
  },
  body: JSON.stringify({
    projectId: project.id,
    prompt: 'Create a button component',
    model: 'llama3.1:latest'
  })
});

// Handle SSE stream
const reader = generateResponse.body.getReader();
const decoder = new TextDecoder();

while (true) {
  const { done, value } = await reader.read();
  if (done) break;

  const chunk = decoder.decode(value);
  const lines = chunk.split('\n');

  for (const line of lines) {
    if (line.startsWith('data: ')) {
      const data = JSON.parse(line.slice(6));
      if (data.chunk) {
        console.log('Code:', data.chunk);
      }
      if (data.done) {
        console.log('Prototype ID:', data.prototypeId);
      }
    }
  }
}

);

docs.title: From localStorage to PostgreSQL
docs.text:
The application previously used localStorage. Here's how to migrate:

Option 1: Fresh Start - Just start using the app - new conversations will be saved to the database

Option 2: Manual Migration 1. Export existing data: 

// In browser console
const data = localStorage.getItem('ollama-chat-conversations');
console.log(JSON.parse(data));

  1. Use the API to import conversations: 

    const conversations = JSON.parse(localStorage.getItem('ollama-chat-conversations'));

for (const conv of conversations) {
  // Create conversation
  const response = await fetch('http://localhost:3001/api/conversations', {
    method: 'POST',
    headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
    body: JSON.stringify({
      title: conv.title,
      model: conv.model
    })
  });
  const newConv = await response.json();

  // Add messages
  for (const msg of conv.messages) {
    await fetch('http://localhost:3001/api/messages', {
      method: 'POST',
      headers: { 'Content-Type': 'application/json' },
      body: JSON.stringify({
        conversationId: newConv.id,
        role: msg.role,
        content: msg.content
      })
    });
  }
}

  2. Clear localStorage (optional): 

    localStorage.removeItem('ollama-chat-conversations');

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) allows applications to provide context (resources, prompts, tools) to LLMs. Integrating an MCP server into localbridge will allow external agents (like Claude Desktop or other MCP clients) to interact with the application's data and agents.

docs.title: 1. Architecture
docs.text: We will implement an MCP Server that runs alongside the existing Express backend. - Transport: Server-Sent Events (SSE) over HTTP is the best fit for a web application backend. We will expose: - GET /api/mcp/sse: For initializing the connection. - POST /api/mcp/messages: For handling client messages.

docs.title: Resources (Data Access)
docs.text:
• Conversations: readable as resources conversation://{id}.
  • Documents: readable as resources document://{id}.
  • Project Files: readable as resources.

docs.title: Tools (Action Execution)
docs.text:
• list_agents: Returns a list of available agents in the system.
  • execute_agent: Allows an external LLM to trigger a localbridge agent to perform a task.
  • create_task: Create a new task in the system.

docs.title: Prompts
docs.text: • system_prompt: Expose the core system prompt used by the application.

docs.title: 3. Implementation Steps
docs.text:
1. Dependencies: Install @modelcontextprotocol/sdk.
  2. Server Implementation: Create server/mcp/server.ts to define the MCP server, capabilities, and request handlers.
  3. Express Integration: Mount the MCP server on the existing Express app in server/index.ts.
  4. Testing: Verify connection using an MCP client inspector or a simple script.

docs.title: Benefits
docs.text:
• Interoperability: Connects localbridge to the broader ecosystem of AI tools.
  • Extensibility: Allows other specialized agents to "hire" localbridge agents for subtasks.
  • Context Sharing: Seamlessly share the application's knowledge base with external models.

docs.title: LocalBridge VS Code Extension Integration Review
Overview
docs.text:
This document reviews the technical feasibility and implementation plan for the LocalBridge VS Code Extension, as identified in the Advanced Features Roadmap (Item #19).

The goal is to allow developers to generate, enhance, and test React components directly within their editor using the LocalBridge AI engine.

docs.title: Backend Readiness
docs.text:
Status: ✅ High Readiness The existing LocalBridge API (server/routes/generate.ts) already exposes the necessary logic for component generation and enhancement. - POST /api/generate/prototype: Can be used for "Generate Component" command. - POST /api/generate/enhance: Can be used for "Refine Selection" or "Inline Chat" commands. - POST /api/generate/tests: Can be used for "Generate Tests" command.

Gap: - Authentication currently relies on a user JWT from the web login. The extension will need a mechanism to authenticate (Login Command) and store this token.

docs.title: Integration Approach
docs.text: We will build a VS Code Extension (Client) that utilizes the LocalBridge API (Server).

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
graph LR
    A[VS Code Extension] -- HTTPS/JSON --> B[LocalBridge API]
    B -- Stream/SSE --> A
    A -- Insert/Diff --> C[Active Editor]

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
1. Command Palette Integration: Register commands like LocalBridge: Generate Component.
  2. Webview UI: (Optional) For complex chat or settings.
  3. Authentication Manager: Handles Login and Token storage (using VS Code SecretStorage).
  4. Generative Service: HTTP client to communicate with /api/generate/*.

docs.title: Proposed Features Phase 1
docs.text: Feature Description API Endpoint Authenticate Login to LocalBridge instance to get Access Token. POST /api/auth/login Generate Component Generate a new component based on a prompt. Inserts code at cursor. POST /api/generate/prototype Enhance Selection Enhance the selected code block based on instructions. POST /api/generate/enhance Generate Tests generate Jest tests for the open file. POST /api/generate/tests

docs.title: Step 1: Initialize Extension Project
docs.text:
• create a new folder extensions/vscode (or separate repo).
  • Use yo code or manual setup for a TypeScript VS Code extension.

docs.title: Step 2: Authentication Flow
docs.text:
• Implement LocalBridge: Login command.
  • Input Box for Email/Password (or later, a Personal Access Token).
  • Call /api/auth/login.
  • Save JWT to context.secrets.

docs.title: Step 3: "Generate Component" Command
docs.text:
• Input Box for "Prompt".
  • Select Model (optional).
  • Call /api/generate/prototype.
  • Handle SSE (Server-Sent Events) stream to show progress in a Status Bar or Output Channel.
  • Insert final code at cursor position.

docs.title: Step 4: "Enhance Selection" Command
docs.text:
• Get editor.selection.
  • Input Box for "Instructions".
  • Call /api/generate/enhance with currentCode + enhancementPrompt.
  • Replace selection with returned code.

docs.title: Step 5: "Generate Tests" Command
docs.text:
• Read entire file content.
  • Call /api/generate/tests.
  • Create a new file (e.g., Component.test.tsx) with the result.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
1. Scaffold the extension structure defined in Step 1.
  2. Test the API from an external client (like Postman or a simple script) to verify CORS and Header requirements (ensure cors middleware allows requests from the extension, or user overrides Origin).

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
• Token Storage: Must use vscode.SecretStorage.
  • CORS: The LocalBridge server must allow calls from the VS Code extension (which might send Origin: vscode-webview:// or null). We may need to update server/index.ts CORS settings.

docs.title: What is LocalBridge?
docs.text: LocalBridge is an enterprise-grade, self-hosted AI prototyping platform that enables teams to generate React/TypeScript code using local LLM models with complete data sovereignty.

docs.title: Key Responsibilities
docs.text: As an administrator, you'll manage: - ✅ System installation and configuration - ✅ User access and permissions - ✅ Security and compliance - ✅ Performance monitoring - ✅ Backups and disaster recovery - ✅ Updates and maintenance

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
System Requirements: - OS: Linux (Ubuntu 20.04+), macOS, or Windows with WSL2 - CPU: 8+ cores recommended - RAM: 16GB minimum, 32GB+ recommended - Storage: 100GB+ SSD - Network: Stable internet for initial setup

Software Requirements: - Node.js 18+ and npm - PostgreSQL 14+ - Ollama (for AI models) - Git - Docker (optional, for containerized deployment)

docs.title: Automated Backups
docs.text:
Create /usr/local/bin/backup-localbridge.sh:

#!/bin/bash
BACKUP_DIR="/var/backups/localbridge"
DATE=$(date +%Y%m%d_%H%M%S)

# Create backup directory
mkdir -p $BACKUP_DIR

# Backup database
pg_dump $DATABASE_URL | gzip > $BACKUP_DIR/db_$DATE.sql.gz

# Keep only last 30 days
find $BACKUP_DIR -name "db_*.sql.gz" -mtime +30 -delete

echo "Backup completed: db_$DATE.sql.gz"

Add to crontab: 

# Daily backup at 2 AM
0 2 * * * /usr/local/bin/backup-localbridge.sh

docs.title: Restore from Backup

docs.text:

  3. Verify data - Check critical tables
  4. Restart services - Bring system back online
  5. Notify users - Communicate status
  6. Post-mortem - Document and prevent recurrence

docs.title: Recovery Point Objective (RPO)
docs.text:
• Target: < 24 hours
  • Daily backups: Maximum 24-hour data loss
  • Consider: More frequent backups for critical systems

  2. Go to http://localhost:8081/register

  4. Register with your details:

  6. Email: Your email address

  7. Password: At least 8 characters

  8. Submit the form:

  9. You will automatically be assigned the admin role
  10. You'll be logged in immediately

docs.title: If Users Already Exist
docs.text: If you've already registered users and need admin access, you have two options:

npm run db:migrate

# Then register as the first user

docs.text:
Run this SQL command to make an existing user an admin:

# Replace 'your-email@example.com' with your actual email

# Then in Drizzle Studio:
# 1. Go to the 'users' table
# 2. Find your user by email
# 3. Change the 'role' field to 'admin'
# 4. Save

Or use psql directly (if you have DATABASE_URL configured):

UPDATE users 
SET role = 'admin' 
WHERE email = 'your-email@example.com';

docs.title: LocalBridge Enterprise User Guide: Assistants, Agents, and Tools
docs.text:
Welcome to the LocalBridge Enterprise User Guide. This document provides a comprehensive walkthrough for creating and managing AI Assistants, specialized Agents, and Custom Tools within the LocalBridge platform.

These features enable you to build a powerful, autonomous AI workforce tailored to your specific enterprise needs—running entirely locally and securely.

docs.title: 1. Core Concepts
docs.text:
Before diving into creation, it's important to understand the hierarchy of components:

  • Assistant: The primary interface for the user. Think of it as a "Department Head" or "Team Lead". It holds the main context, conversation history, and persona. It delegates tasks to Agents.
  • Agent: A specialized worker with a specific role (e.g., " Researcher", "Python Coder", "Legal Analyst"). Agents operate under an Assistant and have specific instructions and autonomy levels.
  • Tool: A specific capability given to an Agent (e.g., "Web Search", "Database Query", "Send Email"). Tools are defined by a function name and a JSON schema describing their parameters.

docs.title: 2. Managing Assistants
docs.text: Assistants are the entry point for all interactions.

docs.title: Creating a New Assistant
docs.text:
1. Open the LocalBridge application.
  2. Click the Assistant Selector dropdown in the top header (defaults to "New Chat" or current assistant name).
  3. Select "Create New" or click the "+" icon in the sidebar.
  4. Fill in the General Settings:
    • Name: distinct name (e.g., "Engineering Lead").
    • Description: Purpose of this assistant.
    • Model: Select a local LLM (e.g., llama3.1:latest).
    • Category: Grouping (Coding, Writing, etc.).
    • System Prompt: The core personality and rules.
      • Enterprise Tip: Be specific about compliance and tone. "You are a helpful assistant" is too vague. Use: "You are a Senior DevOps Engineer. You prioritize security and idempotency in all shell scripts."

docs.title: Advanced Parameters
docs.text:
• Temperature: Controls creativity. Low (0-40) for code/facts; High (70-100) for creative writing.
  • Public/Private: Toggle "Public" to share this assistant template with other users on your local instance (if multi-user is enabled).

docs.title: 3. Specialized Agents
docs.text: Agents are where the real work happens. They allow you to break down complex workflows.

docs.title: Adding an Agent to an Assistant
docs.text:
1. In the Assistant Editor, switch to the "Specialized Agents" tab.
  2. Click "Add Agent".
  3. Configure the Agent:
    • Name: e.g., "Code Reviewer".
    • Role: Select from presets (Researcher, Writer, Coder, etc.) or define a custom one.
    • Instructions: Extremely detailed step-by-step logic for this specific agent.
      • Example: "Review the provided code for SQL injection vulnerabilities. Start by identifying user inputs. Then check if parameterized queries are used."
    • Autonomy Level:
      • Low: Agent must ask for user approval before every tool execution.
      • Medium: Agent can execute safe tools but asks for critical ones.
      • High: Agent runs fully autonomously until the task is done.
    • Priority: (0-100) Higher priority agents are consulted first by the Assistant.

docs.title: 4. Custom Tools
docs.text: Tools provide Agents with the ability to interact with the outside world or perform specific computations.

docs.title: Defining a Tool
docs.text:
In the Agent creation dialog, scroll to the "Tools & Capabilities" section.

  1. Click "Add Tool".
  2. Function Name: The exact function name the AI will call (e.g., lookup_customer_order, generate_report). Use snake_case.
  3. Description: A clear natural language description of what the tool does. The AI uses this to decide when to use the tool.

  4. Parameters (JSON Schema): Define the inputs strictly using JSON Schema. This ensures the AI provides structured, valid data.

docs.title: Example: Customer Lookup Tool
docs.text:
{
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "customerId": {
      "type": "string",
      "description": "The unique ID of the customer (e.g. CUST-123)"
    },
    "includeHistory": {
      "type": "boolean",
      "description": "Whether to fetch order history"
    }
  },
  "required": ["customerId"]
}

docs.title: Best Practices for Tools
docs.text:
• Descriptive Names: search_knowledge_base is better than search.
  • Explicit Descriptions: "Searches the internal Q4 2025 financial documentation for specific keywords."
  • Simple Parameters: Keep schemas flat if possible. Complex nested objects can confuse smaller models.

docs.title: Example: Automated Code Audit System
docs.text:
Assistant: "Tech Lead" * System Prompt: "You oversee a team of developers. Your goal is to ensure code quality standards."

Agent 1: "Security Auditor" * Role: Reviewer * Instructions: "Scan code for OWASP Top 10 vulnerabilities." * Tools: run_static_analysis, check_cve_database

Agent 2: "Refactoring Bot" * Role: Coder * Instructions: "Take the findings from the Auditor and propose code changes." * Tools: apply_git_patch, run_unit_tests

Workflow: 1. User enters: "Audit this file." 2. Tech Lead analyzes request and delegates to Security Auditor. 3. Security Auditor uses run_static_analysis, finds an issue, reports back. 4. Tech Lead delegates to Refactoring Bot to fix it. 5. Refactoring Bot generates code, runs unit_tests. 6. Tech Lead presents the final fixed code to the User.

docs.title: 6. Troubleshooting
docs.text:
• Agent not using tools: Check if the "Description" clearly matches the user's intent. The AI matches intent to description.
  • Invalid Parameter Errors: Verify your JSON Schema in the Tool Manager. Ensure required fields are marked as "required".
  • Looping: If an agent gets stuck in a loop, try lowering its Autonomy Level or refining its Instructions to include explicit "stopping conditions".

LocalBridge Enterprise Edition - Secure, Local, Capable.

docs.title: LocalBridge User Guide
docs.text: Welcome to LocalBridge - Your secure, local-first AI prototyping platform.

docs.title: Table of Contents
docs.text:
1. Getting Started
  2. Creating Your First Project
  3. Generating Prototypes
  4. Managing Projects
  5. GitHub Integration
  6. Tips & Best Practices
  7. Troubleshooting
  8. FAQs

docs.title: What is LocalBridge?
docs.text: LocalBridge is an enterprise-grade AI prototyping platform that helps you generate React/TypeScript code using local AI models. Your data never leaves your infrastructure, ensuring complete privacy and compliance.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• 🤖 AI Code Generation - Generate React components from natural language
  • 🔒 100% Local - All processing happens on your infrastructure
  • 🔐 Enterprise Security - SOC2 compliant with full audit trails
  • 📦 GitHub Integration - Push prototypes directly to your repositories
  • 🎨 Live Preview - See your code running in real-time
  • 🔄 Version Control - Track all prototype iterations

docs.title: Step 1: Log In
docs.text:
1. Navigate to LocalBridge in your browser
  2. Enter your email and password
  3. Click Sign In

Alternative: Use SSO with Google or Microsoft if configured by your administrator.

docs.title: Step 2: Create a Project
docs.text:
1. Click the Projects link in the navigation
  2. Click New Project button
  3. Fill in the project details:
  4. Name: Give your project a descriptive name (e.g., "Dashboard Redesign")
  5. Description: Briefly describe what you're building (optional)
  6. GitHub Repository: Link to your GitHub repo (optional)
  7. Click Create Project

Example: 

Name: Customer Dashboard
Description: Modern dashboard for customer analytics
GitHub Repo: https://github.com/myorg/customer-dashboard

docs.title: Step 3: Access Your Project
docs.text:
1. Find your project in the Projects list
  2. Click on the project card to open it
  3. You're now ready to generate prototypes!

docs.title: Understanding Prototypes
docs.text: A prototype is a React component generated by AI based on your description. Each prototype can have multiple versions as you iterate and refine.

docs.title: Step 1: Write Your Prompt
docs.text:
In the Generate Prototype section:

  1. Enter a clear description of what you want to build
  2. Be specific about functionality and appearance
  3. Mention any specific libraries or patterns

Good Prompt Examples:

✅ Good: 

Create a user profile card with an avatar, name, email, and bio. 
Include edit and delete buttons. Use a modern card design with 
hover effects and make it responsive.

✅ Good: 

Build a data table showing sales data with columns for date, 
product, quantity, and revenue. Include sorting, filtering, 
and pagination. Make it look professional with alternating row colors.

❌ Too Vague: 

Make a form

❌ Too Complex: 

Create a complete e-commerce platform with shopping cart, 
checkout, payment processing, user authentication, admin panel, 
and inventory management.

docs.title: Step 2: Choose Your AI Model
docs.text:
Select the AI model that best fits your needs:

Model Best For Speed Llama 3.1 (Recommended) General code generation Fast Code Llama Specialized coding tasks Fast Qwen 2.5 Coder Advanced code generation Medium DeepSeek Coder Optimized code quality Medium GPT-OSS 120B Complex reasoning Slower

Tip: Start with Llama 3.1 for most tasks.

docs.title: Step 3: Generate
docs.text:
1. Click Generate Prototype
  2. Wait for the AI to generate your code (typically 15-30 seconds)
  3. Watch the code appear in real-time!

During Generation: - ⏱️ You'll see the code streaming in - ❌ You can cancel anytime by clicking the X button - 📊 Progress is shown in real-time

docs.title: Step 4: Preview Your Prototype
docs.text:
Once generation is complete:

  1. The Live Preview will automatically show your component
  2. Interact with it to test functionality
  3. Check if it matches your requirements

Preview Features: - ✅ Real-time rendering - ✅ Interactive elements work - ✅ Responsive design preview - ✅ Error display if any issues

docs.title: Step 5: Iterate if Needed
docs.text:
Not perfect? No problem!

  1. Write a new prompt describing changes
  2. Generate again to create a new version
  3. All versions are saved automatically

Example Iteration: 

First prompt: "Create a login form"
Second prompt: "Add password strength indicator and remember me checkbox"
Third prompt: "Add social login buttons for Google and Microsoft"

docs.title: Viewing All Projects
docs.text:
1. Click Projects in the navigation
  2. See all your projects in a grid layout
  3. Each card shows:
  4. Project name
  5. Description
  6. Number of prototypes
  7. Last updated date

docs.title: Editing a Project
docs.text:
1. Open the project
  2. Click Edit Project (if available)
  3. Update name, description, or GitHub repo
  4. Click Save

docs.title: Deleting a Project
docs.text:
1. Open the project
  2. Click Delete Project
  3. Confirm the deletion

⚠️ Warning: Deleting a project removes all its prototypes. This cannot be undone.

docs.title: Viewing Prototype Versions
docs.text:
1. Open a project
  2. Scroll to the Prototypes section
  3. Click on any prototype to view it
  4. See all versions in the version history

docs.title: Connecting GitHub
docs.text: Prerequisites: - GitHub account - Repository access - GitHub OAuth configured (contact your admin)

docs.title: Pushing to GitHub
docs.text:
1. Generate a prototype
  2. Click Push to GitHub
  3. Select the repository
  4. Choose the branch
  5. Confirm the push

What Gets Pushed: - Complete React component code - All necessary imports - Tailwind CSS styling - TypeScript types

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
✅ Do: - Create a dedicated branch for prototypes - Review code before merging - Test in your local environment - Add to your component library

❌ Don't: - Push directly to main/master - Skip code review - Assume code is production-ready without testing

docs.title: Writing Better Prompts
docs.text:
Be Specific: 

❌ "Create a button"
✅ "Create a primary button with blue background, white text, 
   rounded corners, and a subtle hover effect"

Include Context: 

❌ "Make a chart"
✅ "Create a line chart showing monthly revenue for the past year 
   using recharts library. Include tooltips and a legend."

Break Down Complex Tasks: 

Instead of: "Build a complete dashboard"

Try:
1. "Create a stats card showing total users with an icon"
2. "Create a revenue chart for the last 6 months"
3. "Create a recent activity feed with timestamps"

docs.title: Optimizing Generation Time
docs.text:
1. Keep prompts focused - One component at a time
  2. Use recommended model - Llama 3.1 for speed
  3. Avoid overly complex requests - Break into smaller pieces
  4. Be patient - Quality takes time (15-30 seconds is normal)

docs.title: Version Control Strategy
docs.text:
1. Version 1: Basic structure and layout
  2. Version 2: Add interactivity and state
  3. Version 3: Polish styling and responsiveness
  4. Version 4: Add error handling and edge cases

docs.title: Security Best Practices
docs.text:
✅ Do: - Log out when finished - Use strong passwords - Enable 2FA if available - Report suspicious activity

❌ Don't: - Share your credentials - Leave sessions unattended - Use public computers without logging out - Include sensitive data in prompts

docs.title: Generation Failed
docs.text:
Problem: "Generation failed" error message

Solutions: 1. Check your internet connection 2. Try a simpler prompt 3. Switch to a different AI model 4. Wait a moment and try again 5. Contact support if persists

docs.title: Slow Generation
docs.text:
Problem: Generation taking longer than expected

Solutions: 1. Normal: 15-30 seconds is typical 2. Slow model: Try switching to Llama 3.1 3. Complex prompt: Simplify your request 4. Server load: Try again during off-peak hours

docs.title: Preview Not Showing
docs.text:
Problem: Live preview is blank or showing errors

Solutions: 1. Check browser console for errors (F12) 2. Refresh the page 3. Try regenerating the prototype 4. Clear browser cache 5. Try a different browser

docs.title: Can't Push to GitHub
docs.text:
Problem: GitHub push fails

Solutions: 1. Verify GitHub is connected 2. Check repository permissions 3. Ensure branch exists 4. Contact admin about OAuth setup 5. Try disconnecting and reconnecting GitHub

docs.title: Login Issues
docs.text:
Problem: Can't log in

Solutions: 1. Verify email and password 2. Check Caps Lock is off 3. Try password reset 4. Try SSO if available 5. Contact your administrator

docs.title: General Questions
docs.text:
Q: Is my data secure? A: Yes! All processing happens locally on your infrastructure. Your code and prompts never leave your servers.

Q: How much does it cost? A: Contact your administrator for pricing and licensing information.

Q: Can I use this offline? A: You need internet access to reach the LocalBridge server, but the AI processing happens locally.

Q: What languages are supported? A: Currently, LocalBridge generates React components with TypeScript and Tailwind CSS.

docs.title: Technical Questions
docs.text:
Q: What AI models are available? A: Llama 3.1, Code Llama, Qwen 2.5 Coder, DeepSeek Coder, and GPT-OSS 120B.

Q: How long does generation take? A: Typically 15-30 seconds, depending on complexity and model.

Q: Can I edit the generated code? A: Yes! Copy the code and edit it in your preferred editor. You can also push it to GitHub and edit there.

Q: Are there usage limits? A: Rate limits apply (10 generations per 15 minutes) to ensure fair usage. Contact your admin for enterprise limits.

docs.title: Workflow Questions
docs.text:
Q: Can multiple people work on the same project? A: Yes, if you have the appropriate permissions. Contact your admin about team access.

Q: Can I export my prototypes? A: Yes, copy the code directly or push to GitHub.

Q: How many versions can I create? A: Unlimited! All versions are saved automatically.

Q: Can I delete old versions? A: Currently, all versions are preserved for audit purposes. Contact your admin if you need to remove sensitive data.

docs.text: The prototype generation now dynamically fetches and displays only the AI models that are actually available on the Ollama server.

docs.title: 1. Backend API Endpoint ✅
docs.text:
File: server/routes/models.ts

Features: - GET /api/models endpoint - Fetches available models from Ollama server - Returns model name, size, and last modified date - Graceful error handling if Ollama is unavailable - 5-second timeout to prevent hanging

docs.text:
File: src/pages/ProjectDetail.tsx

Features: - React Query to fetch available models - 5-minute cache to reduce API calls - Loading state while fetching models - Empty state when no models available - Warning message if Ollama is not running - Disabled model selector during loading

docs.title: Enterprise Roadmap: Making LocalBridge Robust
docs.text: To elevate LocalBridge from a capable prototype to an enterprise-grade platform, we recommend implementing the following features and workflows. These additions focus on security, observability, and advanced autonomy.

docs.title: 1. Advanced Agent Runtime (The "Brain" Upgrade)
docs.text: Currently, agents are defined with instructions and tools, but the execution engine is a placeholder. To make agents truly autonomous:

docs.title: Feature: Proper Tool Execution Loop
docs.text: Why: Agents need to actually do things, not just describe them. Workflow: 1. Implement a Tools Registry on the backend (e.g., standard Python/JS sandbox or API connectors). 2. Update the Agent Executor to loop: * Think: LLM decides which tool to call. * Act: Backend executes the specific function (e.g., fetch_url, run_sql). * Observe: Feed the tool output back into the LLM context. * Repeat: Until the task is finished.

docs.title: Feature: Structured Outputs (JSON Mode)
docs.text: Why: Enterprise systems need reliable data, not chatty text. Implementation: Enforce JSON schemas on agent final outputs to ensure easy integration with downstream systems (dashboards, ERPs).

docs.title: 2. Knowledge Base (RAG Integration)
docs.text: Why: An enterprise AI is only as good as the data it knows. Feature: "Chat with Docs" * Vector Database: Integrate pgvector (since we use Postgres/Drizzle) or ChromaDB. * Ingestion Pipeline: Allow users to upload PDFs, CSVs, and Markdown files. * Workflow: 1. User uploads fiscal_report_2024.pdf. 2. System chunks and embeds the text into the vector DB. 3. When user asks "What was Q4 revenue?", the Assistant automatically retrieves relevant chunks before answering.

docs.title: 3. Enterprise Security & Governance
docs.text:
✅ Status: Completed

Why: "Local" is secure, but "Access Control" is mandatory.

docs.title: Feature: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) - [x] Done
docs.text:
• Admin: Manage all assistants and system prompts.
  • Editor: Can create/edit agents but not delete global templates.
  • Viewer: Can only chat with assigned assistants.

docs.title: Feature: Comprehensive Audit Logging - [x] Done
docs.text: Why: Compliance. Implementation: Record every: * Tool execution (input/output). * System prompt change. * User login/logout. * Store these in a tamper-evident audit_logs table.

docs.title: 4. Observability & Analytics Dashboard
docs.text:
✅ Status: Completed

Why: You can't improve what you don't measure. Feature: "Agent Performance Monitor" - [x] Done * Metrics: * Total Executions & Success Rate. * Average Duration. * Top Performing Agents. * Visualization: Interactive Dashboard with charts (Recharts) showing execution volume over time and audit logs.

docs.title: 5. Team Collaboration Features
docs.text:
✅ Status: Completed

Why: Enterprise work is multiplayer. Feature: Shared Workspaces - [x] Done * Forking an Assistant: Fully implemented. Duplicating an assistant now recursively copies all its agents and tools. * Shared Chat History: Implemented shareable links (e.g., /share/:shareId) and "Share" button in Chat Interface. Public access tokens ensure security.

docs.text: This document summarizes the enterprise-grade improvements made to the Generate Prototype module to meet SOC2, ISO27001, and production-ready standards.

docs.title: 1. Comprehensive Audit Logging
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

Changes: - Added audit trail for all generation attempts (success and failure) - Logs include: user ID, IP address, user agent, model used, prompt length, code length, duration - Tracks access denial attempts - Integrated with existing auditLogs table

Files Modified: - server/routes/generate.ts

Impact: - Full compliance with audit requirements - Complete traceability of AI-generated content - Forensic analysis capability

docs.title: 2. Timeout Protection
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

Changes: - Added 2-minute timeout for LLM generation requests - Uses Promise.race() for non-blocking timeout enforcement - Graceful error handling on timeout - Prevents resource exhaustion

Configuration: 

GENERATION_TIMEOUT_MS: 120000 // 2 minutes

Impact: - Prevents indefinite resource locking - Protects against stuck LLM requests - Improves system reliability

docs.title: 3. Request Correlation IDs
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

Changes: - Every request gets a unique UUID correlation ID - Included in all logs, audit entries, and responses - Added X-Correlation-ID response header - Frontend displays correlation ID in error messages

Impact: - End-to-end request tracing - Simplified debugging of production issues - Better customer support capability

docs.title: 4. Input Sanitization
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

Changes: - Sanitizes user prompts to prevent injection attacks - Removes: HTML/XML tags, template literals, code fence attempts - Applied before LLM processing and database storage

Sanitization Rules: 

- Remove <> tags
- Remove ${} template literals
- Remove ``` code fences
- Trim whitespace

Impact: - Protection against prompt injection - Prevents XSS attacks - Secures database integrity

docs.title: 5. Enhanced Code Validation
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

Changes: - Validates minimum code length (10 chars) - Checks for React component structure: - Must have imports - Must have function/component definition - Returns specific validation failure reasons

Impact: - Prevents garbage code from being saved - Improves generated code quality - Better error messages for users

docs.title: 6. Structured Error Handling
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

Changes: - Categorized error types: access_denied, timeout, validation_failed, llm_error, database_error - Development vs production error detail separation - Centralized error messages via constants

Impact: - Better error tracking and analytics - Improved debugging capability - Consistent error responses

docs.title: 7. Performance Metrics Tracking
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

New File: server/lib/metrics.ts

Features: - Records all generation attempts with metadata - Tracks: duration, success rate, model usage, error types - In-memory storage (last 1000 metrics) - Aggregated summary statistics

Metrics Collected: 

{
  correlationId: string;
  userId?: string;
  model: string;
  promptLength: number;
  codeLength: number;
  durationMs: number;
  success: boolean;
  errorType?: string;
  timestamp: Date;
}

API Endpoint: 

GET /api/generate/metrics (admin only)

Impact: - Real-time performance monitoring - Model performance comparison - Error rate tracking - Capacity planning data

docs.title: 8. Structured Logging
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

New File: server/lib/structuredLogger.ts

Features: - JSON-formatted logs for parsing - Log levels: DEBUG, INFO, WARN, ERROR - Automatic correlation ID inclusion - Development vs production modes - Timed operation logging

Usage: 

structuredLogger.info('Generation started', { correlationId, userId });
structuredLogger.error('Generation failed', error, { correlationId });

Impact: - Machine-parseable logs - Better integration with log aggregation tools (Datadog, Splunk, ELK) - Improved debugging efficiency

docs.title: 9. Request Cancellation
docs.text:
Status: ✅ Implemented

Changes: - Backend detects client disconnection - Frontend uses AbortController for cancellation - Cleanup on component unmount - User-friendly cancel button in UI

Frontend: - Added cancel button (red X icon) during generation - Automatic cleanup on page navigation - No error toast on user-initiated cancellation

Backend: - Monitors req.on('close') event - Stops streaming on client disconnect - Logs cancellation events

Impact: - Prevents wasted server resources - Better user experience - Cleaner resource management
